indicators.justification:
In the UK, nature conservation is mainly a devolved responsibility so England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland each have their own strategies for biodiversity.

The Joint Nature Conservation Committee (JNCC)[1] is responsible for the National Report to the Convention on Biological Diversity[2] and deciding on the status of species, coordinating a multi-agency process that involves all the national administrations.[3]  

UK red list data is hosted online by a variety of conservation groups- eg for birds,[4] mammals,[5] butterflies[6]. The JNCC provides a spreadsheet that contains a variety of conservation designation listings - including red lists - for some 13,000 UK  "taxa"[7] but it is not user-friendly. There is no UK red list for every species group, for example, reptiles although there are European ones.[8] 

The UK has legal protections through the Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981,[9] and its schedules contain the lists of protected species[10] and those that can be sold or killed, which are reviewed every 5 years.[11]  Conservation groups working on reptiles and amphibians have complained that relying on red listing for protection is too narrow as it only reaches species at imminent risk of extinction while many are still in danger but could lose protections in the reviews.[12] They also complain that UK legal protections lists focus on intentional killing and less on slower extinction through land use changes.

There are many pieces of EU law requiring species monitoring and reporting but their status is unclear after Brexit.

[2] Fifth National Report to the United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity: United Kingdom, 2014 https://www.cbd.int/doc/world/gb/gb-nr-05-en.pdf

indicators.justification:
The UK implemented the first register of beneficial ownership (termed persons with significant control - PSC) in 2016 and has also transposed the EU's 5th Anti-Money Laundering (AML) Directive, with requirements for a public register of beneficial ownership, which has been maintained after Brexit.[1]

The UK PSC register was praised in 2018 by Global Witness for its accessibility and enhanced scope bringing new legal entities, plus the efforts by Companies House to educate company registrants. However, they also found some issues that remained through the period of the barometer survey. The main problem is that the data is not validated and verified, purely relying on self-reporting, so it is possible to put fake names or addresses. There is no need to present any form of ID. Global Witness also criticised that despite the availability of the register, the government was not using it to proactively identify suspicious entities, particularly new types of company that are less regulated. The public register includes name, month and year of birth but no linking identifier that enables connecting companies to the same person.[2]

The Government agreed in 2020 to introduce compulsory identity verification for all directors, PSCs and people filling in information. Third parties can be tasked with the verification, including registration companies and secretarial services. There are also other proposed changes to require additional information from companies that claim exemption from the PSC register.[3]

The UK has one of the most successful vaccination programmes. Some basic COVID-19 vaccination data in the UK is available in the main open data portal[1] but detailed data is provided separately by the four nations: England,[2] Wales,[3] Scotland[4] and Northern Ireland.

The main gaps in vaccination data relate to the commercial aspects and the availability of vaccines rather than the roll out itself. This is part of a wider problem of lack of transparency and possible corruption over COVID-related contracts.[5]

The UK has a sophisticated system for public finance and reviews to the government budget but not all the underlying data is available as structured open data.[1] There is much financial data available through the Office of National Statistics (ONS)[2] and some budget data is available through the Office of Budget Responsibilit[3]y, which also publishes the Economic and fiscal outlook with all underlying data.[4]

indicators.justification:
The UK presents a mixed picture. Public procurement data is available online on two main platforms, Contracts Finder[1] and Find a Tender[2] for high value tenders, plus in a variety of local and regional sites. Unfortunately, the tenders available on the central sites miss some 70% of public sector requests.[3] When data is available it is open, machine readable and conforming to Open Procurement Data Standard.[4]

While data on tenders can be found, even if through huge technical efforts to make it comprehensive, there is no data on awarded contracts available to the public, only suppliers registered with the systems. There are third party tools that scrape Contracts Finder and other sites to present this information but it is not known how patchy it may be.[5] 

The situation is worse for tracking the delivery of contracts, where there is more limited information. At the time of the 2018 collapse of strategic supplier Carillion the government had spent months trying to get a complete picture and were still unable to get all data for local contracts.[6] 

The COVID crisis has created an unprecedented crisis of confidence on public procurement. In the months up to July 2020 new contracts worth £17.3 billion were awarded to suppliers,  £10.5 billion without any competition.[7] Transparency International has raised possible corruption concerns in contracts worth £3.7 billion.[8]

A complete planned overhaul of UK public procurement after Brexit was outlined in a green paper at the end of 2020.[9] This will make it compulsory for all contracting bodies to use the Open Contracting Data Standard to enable analysis by public bodies. The Code of Practice on Consultation⁠[1] sets out guidance on how to publish information as part of the responsiveness principle. After a consultation and before further action,  "the Government should provide a summary of who responded to the consultation exercise and a summary of the views expressed to each question. A summary of any other significant comments should also be provided. This feedback should normally set out what decisions have been taken in light of what was learnt from the consultation exercise."

Respondents should be alerted to the publication of the government response and there should be "consideration" to publishing individual responses, although this is not compulsory.

The Code is a policy document that only applies to specific central government departments, although other public bodies are encouraged to use it. It does not have legal force and cannot prevail over statutory or mandatory requirements. 

There is a wider public duty to consult in certain cases covered by statutory requirements and also when there is. Legitimate expectation from common law. These criteria have been developed through jurisprudence, but the cases tend to focus on failures to reach affected people and not on the publication of information as such.[2]

The overall process for consultation is not formally regulated. The Government may start by publishing policy papers for discussion, which are normally covered by the Code, but at some point, it publishes a Draft Bill for consultation and pre-legislative scrutiny[3]. At this stage, external input goes through submissions to various committees of Parliament[4] where amendments may be presented. These committees tend to publish all public responses but there is no set rule

indicators.justification:
The UK was a pioneer in the development of civic technology and accountability data, such as the WhatDoTheyKnow[1] tool from MySociety, but in the past few years this has partially stagnated. There are a few initiatives to crowdsource information and increase political engagement, but less use of available data for advocacy and accountability.[2]
There are some good examples though.  Tax Justice Network has used data analytics on the beneficial ownership register to find entities with opaque ownership chains.[3] Transparency International has collated data on official meetings and has built a tool to explore it.[4] Other civil society organisations have used land data to advocate for equality,[5] (WhoOwnsEngland) transparency and environmental issues[6] (Friends of the Earth).

Mainstream media in the UK were very active in the use of open data years back, but currently there are fewer articles. They will pick up some of the work carried by other projects such as OpenDemocracy or Private Eye. OpenDemocracy,  for example, analysed political donations to expose that 20% of all political donations came from men.[7] They also challenged the Chair of UK Parliament's lobbying watchdog for lack of transparency in his own declarations.[8]
 OpenDemocracy had sued the Cabinet Office over its secret unit to vet FOIA requests.[9] Private Eye pioneered the reuse of public data plus comprehensive FOI requests to account for land ownership by offshore firms.[10]
MySociety has been running several tools for transparency for many years, such as the pioneering This tool has been very successful for accountability but it supports requests to government and not proactive disclosure and open data.

Academia shows fewer examples, but researchers have found that only 4% of people recorded in ministerial meetings were registered in the lobbyists register, while 29% of those in the register did not appear in any records of meetings. Overall their report "puts the UK as among the least robust of lobbying regulation regimes."[11]
